comment.narrative:
- The Property Tax Law Review Committee has submitted a draft Property Tax Law to the Office of the Minister of Finance.
- 47 municipalities are implementing a nationwide decentralized and well managed property tax collection system established through Phase I of the project It is expected that 5 more municipalities will establish this system by the end of Phase 1 (52 municipalities).
- Lack of timely assessment and valuation adjustments produces slower growth rate in the property tax revenue collection compared with that of the national income.
- The property tax collection and expenditure information is not shared with tax payers, limiting the transparency in the system.
- The compliance rate is low; property tax collection rate stands at 52%.

Final draft law completely translated.
Meetings held between MoF, MoMA, GAM and other parties - instructions procedures and guidelines have been finalised and approved by the relevant authorities.

description.narrative: 1. Number of newly constructed roads. 2. Square meters of maintained road. 3. Number of lighting poles erected on site. 4. Number of signs posted. 5. Number of trees planted around the site. 6. Building being rehabilitated. 7. New gate house is being constructed with video audio aids. 8. Sanitary landfill cell excavated. 9. Leachate collection system installed. 10. Liner system in place. 11. Number of new equipment that will be added to the workshop. 12. Better cleaning and maintenance of the landfill equipment.

comment.narrative:
Baseline for Output I: 1. Alakedir landfill is considered as one of the hotspots in Jordan, which used for the disposal of both solid and liquid wastes. 2. The landfill receives the solid waste generated by about 100 towns, villages and communities in northern Jordan. 3. The landfill started operation back in 1980. The criteria used in the site selection was mainly based on pure economic considerations, without taking into account other landfill selection criteria 4. Due to its environmental and health impacts the landfill was the subject of national debate. 5. As a result of the Syrian refugee crises, the amounts of solid waste disposed at Alakedir site have increased from 800 tons in 2010 to 1200 tons in 2014. 6. The landfill infrastructure has been deteriorated. 7. The landfill employees offices and accommodation buildings are deteriorating 8. The landfill entrance building is very small and does not serve the purpose of controlling and monitoring the solid waste shipments 9. The current landfilling process is unsanitary one that is lacking leachate and biogas control and management. 10. The estimated annual leachate volume that is generated from the landfill is 7265 m3 11. Well identified operational plan to spread, compact and fill the solid waste in cells does not exist. 12. The existing landfill workshop equipment is deteriorated. 13. No washing machine for the equipment
Baseline Output II: 1. The landfill is located at a distance from the solid waste generation sites. 2. Collection vehicles spending long time on transport route not on the collection routes 3. Relatively high transport cost 4. Traffic congestion on the roads
Target: 10 to 12 % of solid waste is recycled. 70% of hazardous waste is treated, including medical and chemical
12% of the solid waste has been recycled. 70% of hazardous waste has been treated.

Output 1: •Finalize design, bill of quantities, technical specifications, and all requirements to be ready for tendering and 50% of the infrastructure of the administrative building completed.
Output 2: •Design of the new sanitary landfill cell •Finalise the EIA for Al-Ekaider landfill •Tendering process for the new sanitary landfill cell. •Preparatory works to start the delivery of the new sanitary landfill cell
Output 3: •Finalise locations and all related issues to the location •Elaboration of environmental and social impact assessment (ESIA) •Finalise the ESIA for Al-Ekaider landfill to reach the stage of getting official approval •Finalize 90% of the design of the transfer station in Jerash
Output 4: •Delivery of around 100% of the requested machinery and equipment
Output 5: N/A
Output 6: •Finalise the “Strengthening the Human Capacities of JSC Irbid at the Landfill Level for Optimizing the Viability and Performance of Waste Disposal Operations at Al-Ekaider Landfill Site” •A learning visit to Turkey is conducted. •Integrated solid waste management training conducted. •Fleet management training conducted. •Financial management training conducted.
Output 7: •Reporting the environmental baseline of the current animal manure management at Al-Mafraq Governorate. •Establishing a pilot open windrow composting facility (30 tons/day, small-medium scale) within Al-Hussainyyat landfill site. •Provision of the infrastructure, equipment, and tools needed for the proper operation and manure-based compost industry. •Provision of the state of the art technologies, know-how and technical knowledge for open aerobic windrow composting and the relevant capacity building and educational training for the working staffs.
Output 8: •Development of a partnership model for local community engagement in the operational phase based on the operational and Marketing plans. •Implementing a pilot project for producing organic manure-based compost products through financially we

1. The Administrative building is 75% completed. 2. The EIA was done and completed. 3. Phase #1 (Design Review) of the landfill cell and phase #2 (Bidding Support Services) while phase III (Construction Supervision & Management) is ongoing. 4. Heavy machinery and equipment were delivered and handed over to AL-Aikader landfill. 5.Environmental and Social Impact Study (ESIA) for the Transfer Station in Jerash was conducted and we are waiting for MoEnv's approval 6. 90% of the design of the Jerash transfer station was finalized. 7. Capacity building was conducted and different training were held (Integrated solid waste management training, fleet management training,Financial management training.)
1.The completion and opening of the administrative building. 2. Finalizing the construction of the landfill cell. 3. Finalizing the design of Jerash transfer station.

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

- Consideration of biodiversity in plans and policies for tourism development by government, planning authorities and the private sector - Level of consideration for biodiversity conservation in tourism development proposals - Hectares of landscape where impacts on biodiversity are avoided, mitigated or offset --Total annual revenue earned from tourism operations in targeted PAs

comment.narrative: - No explicit reflection of biodiversity priorities - While energy and water feature in environmental considerations at present, biodiversity does not - No planning provisions for the protection of biodiversity outside formal PAs - Annual revenue: Dibeen Forest Reserve: US$ 43,000, Wadi Rum PA: US$ 976,467

- SEA for tourism development to inform biodiversity considerations clarified - spatial areas where development should be avoided identified, and needed mitigation and offset requirements identified. - A biodiversity-friendly tourism charter including a set of standards developed tested and adopted for the MoTA. - EIA Process to tourism developments and operations applied. - Biodiversity Information Management System (BIMS), founded on initial ecological surveys to inform Land-Use Plans. - Comprehensive land-use plans based on BIMS and covering Jerash Governorate, PDTRA territory, Petra proposed PA and its buffer zone, and the Greater Wadi Rum Landscapes/Development Zones to set development limits so as to protect biodiversity. - Effective interpretation and information facilities at vantage points to inform visitors about the values and vulnerabilities of ecological resources and the consequences (ecological and legal) of not adhering to limits and regulations. - PAP nomination file developed and approved. - Dibeen PA, Management Plans revised. - Visitor management capabilities (to reduce impact on biodiversity) in Dibeen, Petra and Wadi Rum PAs enhanced. - Business plans for Wadi Rum PAs developed.

 SEA & EIA; - Producing the guidelines for mainstreaming biodiversity in EIA system for tourism projects - Producing monitoring programmes for the Effectiveness of SEA and EIA Process for Biodiversity and Tourism - ASEZA positively accepted to engage BITS Project and its EIA/SEA consultant and the consultation group in the revision of their EIA regulations and to suggest articles for SEA - The SEA specific articles draft as part of the review process of the national EIA bylaw was developed, shared and agreed by all partners.
 Biodiversity-friendly tourism legal framework; - Formal agreement to establish a green unit at MoTA and adapt green strategies within the ministry of Tourism achieved, and also discussed with the private tourism sector and approved it. - Green unit governance system report (including mandate, positioning, structure, resources) submitted discussed and approved by MoTA. - Comprehensive land-use plans based on BIMS initiated for RUM, Dibbin and Petra sites BIMS; - hardware for the central unit purchased, and the field surveys began. Situation analysis report, research gap analysis, survey design, meeting with stakeholders in Dibbin and Amman held, the training needs for Petra, rum, and Dibbin assessed. - The sites equipment purchased.
 PAP (Petra Archeological Park) - First 0 draft nomination file draft submitted and discussed with PDTRA.
Management Plan ( Dibbin): - Dibbin management plan proposal developed (agreed) and submitted by RSCN.  Interpretation and visitor management capabilities; - A situation analysis study assess and analyses the current situation with respect to interpretation and Visitor’s management capabilities submitted revised, shared and approved by all relevant partners. - Quick wins action plans implemented. ( ECOLOO toilet, some singes in Petra, Kiosk, etc)

- A biodiversity-friendly tourism charter including a set of standards developed tested and adopted for the MoTA certification schemes for hotels, eco-tour operators, eco-lodges and environmental camp sites. - Biodiversity guidelines for the EIA Process as it applies to tourism developments and operations with particular focus on off-site and cumulative impacts. - Economic incentives and disincentives to promote adherence by tourism industry to the reformed policies and regulation. - Biodiversity Information Management System (BIMS), founded on initial ecological surveys to inform Land-Use Plans, serve as a platform for decision-making, and as a source of up to date knowledge on biodiversity. - Comprehensive land-use plans based on BIMS and covering Jerash Governorate, PDTRA territory, the Petra proposed PA and its buffer zone, and the Greater Wadi Rum Landscapes/Development Zones to set development limits so as to protect biodiversity. - Biodiversity Monitoring System to update and maintain the BIMS, identify trends and ensure that any changes in biodiversity-important areas remain within acceptable limits; to include remedial measures that will be triggered by the monitoring. Include the use of indicator species as appropriate. - Effective interpretation and information facilities at vantage points to inform visitors about the values and vulnerabilities of ecological resources and the consequences (ecological and legal) of not adhering to limits and regulations. - PA Management Advisory Boards for promoting increased involvement of the private sector and local community in PA management. - Dibeen PA, Petra PA and Wadi Rum PA Management Plans revised to reflect the principles espoused in the new Land Use plans and the benefits from new BIMS and Monitoring System. - Visitor management capabilities (to reduce impact on biodiversity) in Dibeen, Petra and Wadi Rum PAs, enhanced through improved visitor facilities, better trained rangers and eco-guides, and

o biodiversity-friendly tourism charter; - Standard and certification review report is submitted, reviewed and approved. - A final version of the legal charter –phase I- reports have been submitted with insights and recommendations for future follow up to enhance mainstreaming of natural heritage and biodiversity conservation in MoTA and the tourism sector.
o Biodiversity Information Management System (BIMS); - All surveys and reports have been submitted and approved. - BIMS was launched in a ceremony held in Oct.
Comprehensive land-use plans - Total of 44,541 hectares in Petra Landscape covered by the second phase of land use plan implemented by BITS project which considers biodiversity component within the legal context. - Total area of 60,000 Hectares in Wadi Rum is covered by the protected area buffer zone plan. - A total area of 13,700 hectares is covered by the second phase of the land use plan, which based on the first phase findings, the second phase aimed at developing a land use plan that covers the surrounding area of “Dibbin Forest Reserve”, and the sought land use plan should insure the sustainability of natural and cultural assets of Dibbin protected area.
- Interpretation activities including the development of 3 documentaries about Rum, Petra and Dibbin implemented.

- A biodiversity-friendly tourism charter including a set of standards developed tested and adopted for the MoTA certification schemes for hotels, eco-tour operators, eco-lodges and environmental camp sites. - Biodiversity guidelines for the EIA Process as it applies to tourism developments and operations with particular focus on off-site and cumulative impacts. - Economic incentives and disincentives to promote adherence by tourism industry to the reformed policies and regulation. - Comprehensive land-use plans based on BIMS and covering Jerash Governorate, PDTRA territory, the Petra proposed PA and its buffer zone, and the Greater Wadi Rum Landscapes/Development Zones to set development limits so as to protect biodiversity. - Biodiversity Monitoring System to update and maintain the BIMS, identify trends and ensure that any changes in biodiversity-important areas remain within acceptable limits; to include remedial measures that will be triggered by the monitoring. Include the use of indicator species as appropriate. - Effective interpretation and information facilities at vantage points to inform visitors about the values and vulnerabilities of ecological resources and the consequences (ecological and legal) of not adhering to limits and regulations. - PA Management Advisory Boards for promoting increased involvement of the private sector and local community in PA management. - Dibeen PA, Petra PA and Wadi Rum PA Management Plans revised to reflect the principles espoused in the new Land Use plans and the benefits from new BIMS and Monitoring System. - Visitor management capabilities (to reduce impact on biodiversity) in Dibeen, Petra and Wadi Rum PAs, enhanced through improved visitor facilities, better trained rangers and eco-guides, and improved management capacities, to expand visitor attractions and improve visitor experience while reducing impact on biodiversity in sensitive areas. - Business plans for Dibeen and Petra PAs

description.narrative: Biodiversity Conservation Objectives are Effectively Mainstreamed and Advanced into and through tourism sector development in Jordan
Consideration of biodiversity in plans and policies for tourism development by government planning authorities and the private sector

comment.narrative: No explicit reflection of biodiversity priorities
At least 80 of known and available plans and policies for tourism development incorporate biodiversity priorities

20 achieved
At this point biodiversity is not clearly depicted in the tourism policies and plans However MoTA incorporates general environmental protection and ecofriendly practices with focus on lowering water and energy consumption and using renewable energy resources
The achieved 20 is based on the following facts
A green unit has been recently established to serve as a policy tool to mainstream green practices particularly in relation to biodiversity conservation
Furthermore the new investment Law No 30 for the Year 2014 which gave a clear and direct highlight on the role of Jordan Investment Commission JIC in protection of the environmental water resources natural resources and biodiversity in line with the environmental law regulations and instruments and in close coordination with the relevant bodies
Its important to mention that The National Tourism Strategy NTS 20112015 is a private sectorled with public sector partnership The strategic objective of the Pillar 4 Enabling Environment is to Enhance Jordans business operational regulatory environmental and institutional settings to underpin the drive for improved competitiveness which gave a clear and direct highlight on the importance of environment and sustainability by adopting initiatives that protect and preserve the environment
The project is currently assessing existing legal and institutional setups with attempt to identify policy gaps to be addressed later

description.narrative: Hectares of landscape where impacts on biodiversity are avoided mitigated or offset

comment.narrative: No planning provisions for the protection of biodiversity outside formal PAs
Some 180000 hectares covered by biodiversityfriendly landuse plans effectively preventing impact on biodiversity

91659 hectares
Total of 17459 hectares in Petra Landscape covered by comprehensive land use plan that considers biodiversity component Of which 11900 hectares covered by PAP Buffer land use plan the plan aimed at ensuring the integrity of the ecological cultural and archeological values within the Petra archeological Park PAP
Tow expansion areas have been covered by land use plans that also ensure the integrity of the ecological cultural and natural values within Petra landscape With a total area of 5559 hectares
The project will pursue its effort to enhance the enforcement of the policies and regulatory frameworks as related to land use planning within Petra land scape
Wadi Rum area a total area of 74200 hectares is covered by zoning plan within Rum PA as part of the master management plan The whole management plan and its zoning plans designed to conserve the ecological and cultural values
The project concluded the consultation phase with ASEZA and other concerned stakeholders to identify and prioritize the land use planning priorities based on which it was decided to address the issue of developing a comprehensive land use plan for the buffer zone of Rum that addresses the ecological values and integrity of the protected area The sought land use plan should insure the sustainability of natural and cultural assets of Rum protected area and maintaining associated ecosystem services The new land use plan will cover another 60000 hectares
Given the complications of land use planning component across the three sites and provided that there are existing ongoing initiatives the project started with extensive scoping assignment in order to understand the current situation and to identify possible incremental support in each site that complements and builds on existing land use practices The scoping study revealed the gaps and priorities in each site it also resulted with priority interventions in each site for instance it was revealed the buffer zone of Rum PA is a top priority as far as the biodiversity conservation is conserved The study included deep analysis of legal set up institutional set up technical and human capacities data management and existing monitoring regimes

description.narrative: Level of consideration for biodiversity conservation in tourism development proposals

comment.narrative: While energy and water feature in environmental considerations at present biodiversity does not
100 of proposals for tourism development consider biodiversity conservation seriously

To date 5 of the new proposals for tourism development considers biodiversity explicitly In preparation to achieving this target the project has been working hardly on establishing green unit under the umbrella of MoTA the unit has been approved by the minister and private sector board to be added to the existing structure As per the preliminary design of the unit it will be attached to licensing and classification department to ensure proper integration of biodiversity considerations in all new tourism proposals As soon as it comes to function the percentage will considerably increase

Business planning for Rum PA is planned to take place in the second half 2015
The three PAs still rely almost entirely on government grants little changes have occurred in the reporting period

comment.narrative: 0 ha

Jerash Governorate Aleppo Pine Pinus halepensis Forests 6200 ha
Petra Region Hisheh Forest Quercus coccifera 300 ha
Wadi Rum Landscape Sand Dune vegetation Haloxylon persicum type 8900 ha

830 hectares in Aleppo pine forest
In case of Aleppo pine forest in an attempt to reduce adverse impact from tourism activities on the forest the project supported the design of a new alternative picnicking site the new site once constructed will be used for heavy tourism activities by this the Aleppo pine forest will be given the opportunity to rehabilitate and relax with much less tourism pressure The project managed to leverage extra financial resources from the Royal Court to fund the construction phase of the alternative site
The first phase of the land use planning component was a preparatory phase in which a comprehensive analysis for the current situation in all project sites was done based on this review an action plans and major gaps were identified The second phase will be informed by the first phase and will cover 60000 hectares as a buffer zone for Wadi Rum PA which will include the Sand dune vegetation 8900 ha and will positively affect the conservation of this important vegetation type
For Hisheh site based on the first phase showed that PDTRA was intensively working on the land use activities recently the project intervention in the second phase will be focused on the legal and enforcement levels the current land use plans suggest Hisheh area as a green area

Enhanced credibility of licensing and permitting authorities as a result of an improved basis for decisionmaking arising from sound data and information and effective monitoring system

0
The project is in process of finalizing biodiversity information management system BIMS which is GISweb based system The BIMS is meant to establish sound data and information and effective monitoring system at the regional level it will also serve the land use planning purposes by offering reliable data and information for NHS layers and ultimately for licensing and permitting procedures It important to mention that local and national authorities would have access to BIMS to be used for more reliable decision making
On the other hand the establishment of the green unit within MoTA will sever as a national monitoring and control system for new tourism developments based on which the MoTA will be enabled to make decisions properly

description.narrative: The place of biodiversity in the legal and procedural framework for tourism planning development and operations

comment.narrative: Biodiversity considerations are currently absent from the framework
Biodiversity elements are integratedincorporated in the legal and procedural framework for tourism planning development and operations

The project continued its effort to assist MoTA in the process of revising the legal and institutional frameworks by conducting a comprehensive and critical review of the existing legal and institutional set ups the assessment revealed that currently there is poor reference to issue of protecting the natural heritage and biodiversity in the tourism related legal framework under the Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities Most of the provisions of laws and regulations only enforce protection to archeological sites and lack for natural heritage aspect There is a genuine opportunity to modify the legal framework of the tourism sector embarking on the recently reactivated council so called the Higher Tourism Council based on Article 5 under the tourism law the council that includes a representation of the MoEnv is responsible for setting the general policy of the sector and its strategies as well as setting modifications for the regulations The project will continue working with the council to mainstream biodiversity friendly tools and instruments
A green unit has been recently established to serve as a policy tool to mainstream green practices particularly in relation to biodiversity concentration

activity-description.narrative: Nation Wide

description.narrative: policy, planning and administration

Indicator Output 1; - National Agenda 2005-2016 updated within the national and regional developments context and launched as the New Economic and Social framework for Jordan 2015-2025 - Executive Development Plan (EDP) updated and linked to Development Framework Indicator output 2: - stakeholder analysis conducted - updating Existing Social Accounting Matrix (SAM) - Conducting new local and national Consultations to revise the national agenda - reviewing the 23 Policy option papers for the Poverty reduction strategy. - Reviewing the Executive Development Plan (EDP). - Middle class assessment report updated - Quality of life Report updated - Povertyy Status report updated Indicators Output 3 : - A new M&E system established at Prime Ministry to monitor the implementation of new framework - The new M&E system is connected with MOPIC to Monitor the implementation of EDP - A dedicated M&E staff is assigned from line ministries to report online on the new framework and EDP - 10% of MOPIC and Prime Ministry concerned staff have strategic planning skills - A dedicated M&E unit at MOPIC and Prime Ministry, and No dedicated staff with M&E skills - 2 concerned staff with modelling capacities - 1 staff from each Line ministry with capacities to report online on the EDP and new framework MIS. Indicators Output 4: A Participatory media and communication strategy in place 1 dedicated staff to work on the communication strategy A national interactive website for the new Development framework established

comment.narrative: Baseline Output 1; - Existing National Agenda 2005-2016 not updated within the national and regional development Baseline output 2: - No stakeholder analysis - Existing Social Accounting Matrix (SAM) - Previous Consultations established through post 2015 agenda, and for the government 2013 action plan. - 23 Policy option papers for the Poverty reduction strategy. - Current National agenda and Executive Development Plan (EDP). - Middle class assessment report not updated - Quality of life Report not updated - Povertyy Status report not updated Baseline Output 3 : - No M&E system to monitor the implementation of new framework and EDP - No dedicated M&E staff from line ministries to report online on the EDP and national agenda - 10% of MOPIC and line ministries concerned staff have strategic planning skills - No dedicated M&E unit at MOPIC and Line Ministries, and No dedicated staff with M&E skills - No staff with modelling capacities - 1 staff from each Line ministry with capacities to report online on the EDP and new framework MIS. Baseline Output4: No Participatory media and communication strategy in place No dedicated staff to work on the communication strategy No national interactive website for the national agenda

1. National circumstances: An initial report was prepared and reviewed by the project management team.

GHG inventories for 2010 and 2012: - Requested activity data were received from all experts and the IPCC 2006 Guidelines for the various sectors were consulted to make sure the requested activity data were accurate and complete. Letters were prepared to ministries and institutions with the help of project assistant based at the Ministry of Environment ( Annex 1) - Received data from different ministries and institutions were sent to relevant experts to start working on their sector. - Follow up letters were prepared with the experts names to facilitate collecting the needed data for the inventory estimation by the experts ( Annex 2) - The energy sector/fuel combustion activities (except transport)- sub sector was prepared and under currently review. - The experts were notified to start using the software before RSS hold another training session on the IPCC software. - The IPCC 2006 introductory and energy sector online course were completed by RSS.
3. GHG Mitigation Actions Assessment: - One to one follow up meetings were held with the Primary Energy/Energy Demand expert and the Transport expert separately to make sure both are working on the right track in terms of the assumptions for the baseline scenario and data requirements and runs of the LEAP software. - Brief reports for Renewable Energy, Energy Efficiency, Primary Energy/Energy Demand, Transport, Waste and Industrial processes sectors were received and reviewed highlighting country-specific trends, plans and policies prevailing within the local context and main assumptions for the baseline scenarios, reports were commented. - Report of the Agriculture is under process. - The Stockholm Environment Institute was contacted to deliver a training in Jordan for the LEAP software. Terms of reference were prepared and we received a CV and a preliminary agenda from the trainer (Annex 3). - The training w

independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: Mainstreaming Rio Convention Provisions into National Sectoral Policies

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

? Global environmental priorities are mainstreamed into National Rangeland Strategy, National Drought Management Action Plan, and National Energy Efficiency Action Plan ? Overall awareness of the value provided by global environmental management is improved in all segments of society

comment.narrative: ? Jordan’s institutional arrangements for environmental management are scattered ? Poor institutionalization of environmental issues into national developmental planning and policy-making ? Environmental management is largely being implemented by NGOs ? In addition to the restricted access to environmental data and information, there are also real deficiencies in the amount of consistent and reliable data that is available. ? Lack of effective national coordination ? General lack of awareness for the public in general, within sectoral institutions, and all the way up to the members of Parliament ? At present, there is an insufficient understanding of the value that the Rio Conventions can contribute to national socio-economic development by facilitating environmentally sound and sustainable developmen
- Inception phase

- The project was officially released on January 7, 2016 . The launching ceremony was preceded with a technical inception workshop convened on December 17, 2015. The technical workshop was attended by a wide spectrum of the project stakeholders’ representatives.

- SWOT and Gap analyses of Jordan’s policy and institutional framework for Rio Convention implementation - Strengthening inter-ministerial communication, coordination, and collaboration on Rio Convention mainstreaming - Rio Convention mainstreaming in National Rangeland Strategy - Rio Convention mainstreaming in the National Drought Management Action Plan -Resource mobilization to replicate Rio Convention mainstreaming -Awareness-raising workshops on linkages between Rio Conventions and socio-economic development -Training programme and accompanying knowledge materials - Awareness-raising workshops on linkages between Rio Conventions and socio-economic development -Institutional and legal set ups related to drought management revamped, this includes strengthening coordination mechanisms among different stakeholders

-The project produced a set of Guidelines for Mainstreaming Rio Conventions into National Priority Strategies, in particular the Rangelands Strategy and the Drought Resilience strategy and Action Plan. -The National Task Force on the inter-ministerial communication &coordination was convened and proposed the restructuring of the three Rio Committees in a way that strengthening their role in the decision making process and ensure integrated implementation of the global environment in the multi-sectoral development strategies in Jordan. The Task force members delegated the unit of legal affairs at MoEnv to draft the new structure in cooperation and technical support from legal affairs expert. -A national consultant was recruited to develop and deliver a training curriculum for the media sector in Jordan on the effective coverage and writing on the global and national environmental issues. The consultant identified in participation with multi-stakeholders from the media sector the urgent needs of knowledge and skills that should be acquired by media representatives to cover the environmental issues. In this response, a training workshop will be carried out during 19-21 October 2016 and target approximately 30 media professionals. -Training Needs Assessment to define the technical cross-cutting competencies required in the line-ministries to mainstream Rio principles in their operational strategies/plans was conducted, accordingly, training matrix was prepared with resource mobilization scheme to operationalize the training plan. -A training workshop on “Global Environment Advocacy” was conducted by the project during 26-27 September 2016 at Ajlun Forest Nature Reserve. The training was attended by 32 participants representing several government sectoral institutions, NGOs, and local administration entities. The training aimed at providing the participants with the basic knowledge and skills required to design advocacy programs on the global and national environment

comment.narrative: 1- Reduced ability to manage and implement the Youth Strategy and Implementation Plan; unclear roles and responsibilities between the Council and the Fund. 2- No clear coordinating entity; no live mapping tool; replicated projects; reduced impact. 3- Youth feeling not involved substantively in decision making and development initiatives; limited opportunities for youth to practice and experience responsibility and accountability; Youth Centers underutilized and not impact.

- Unit established with shadow team. - Existing coordination gaps and overlap of responsibilities are mapped. - Number of meetings held with major concerned government and development organizations for reviewing prioritization of projects. - Live mapping tool created and official communication channels established. - Number of coordination meetings held with agencies implementing major youth initiatives
To be completed on milestone basis.

- Establishment and recruitment of an Advisory and Management Unit. - Finalization of the National Youth Strategy (2016-2018) (NYS). - Developing a workable and credible online M&E system. - Capacity building of HCY and YSF staff on strategic management - Awareness raising of Youth centres’ staff on strategic management and Sustainable Development Goals - Providing support to implementation of the NYS through an effective Monitoring and Evaluation System. - Resource mobilization for key projects. - Capacity assessment and revitalization of Youth centres. - Youth awareness raising on parliamentary elections. - Developing the National Youth Empowerment Strategy. - MoY as a mapping entity for youth initiatives and projects.

- AMU established and operational. - Revision of the National Youth Strategy (2016-2018) and providing the ministry with a detailed report on necessity of developing a new strategy due to many drawbacks and shortcomings in the approved one. - UNDP, through the project, lead the process of developing a new National Youth Empowerment Strategy, in consultation with UN sister agencies. - Recruitment of two senior coordinators to work on improving and National Youth Empowerment Strategy and a three-year action plan. - Capacity of the Ministry of Youth’s staff enhanced on strategic management and Sustainable Development Goals. - A joint initiative on development of the national youth empowerment strategy was agreed upon by UN agencies and lead by UNDP. - Financial resources were mobilized for assessment mapping of youth centres, through UNDP’s PVE Project. - Production of two videos encouraging Youth to participate in the 2016 elections.

- Developing the National Youth Empowerment Strategy (2017-2025) with a three- year action plan. - Developing a robust Monitoring and Evaluation online system for the strategy follow up of implementation. - Resource mobilization for youth projects and initiatives. - Revitalization of 6 youth centres. - Launching an initiative for mapping and unification of youth initiatives under one umbrella.

1. The higher steering committee for the National Youth Empowerment Strategy was assigned 2. Creation of an online share folder for the National Youth Empowerment Strategy
